title: How has understanding about the physical world changed?

summary.text: Light is a transverse electromagnetic wave. Accelerating charges create changing electric fields, which create changing magnetic fields, which create changing electric fields... This self-sustaining dance propagates at speed c.

importance.text: Unifies electricity, magnetism, and light. Shows why nothing beats light speed—it's baked into the fabric of electric and magnetic fields. Every photon is a ripple in the electromagnetic field.

explanations.text: Because accelerating charges disturb the electric field. This disturbance can't stay local—Maxwell's equations demand it propagates. Electric changes cause magnetic changes cause electric changes.

Wave function describes probability amplitudes. Spreads like wave, collapses to particle on measurement. The quantum state |ψ⟩ evolves continuously (wave-like) but measurements give discrete outcomes (particle-like).
Complementarity is fundamental. Position and momentum, wave and particle—these are incompatible observables. Heisenberg uncertainty ΔxΔp ≥ ℏ/2 ensures you can't have both simultaneously.
Not wave. Not particle. Quantum.
Gauge symmetry of electromagnetism. The U(1) symmetry of EM requires massless force carriers (photons) that travel at c. Light speed isn't about light—it's the speed of causality itself.
Wiggling charges → rippling fields → light.

questions.text: What produces electromagnetic waves?

options.explanation: Stationary charges create static electric fields, not waves. Waves need change.
Constant velocity means no acceleration. Moving charges create magnetic fields but no waves.
Correct! Acceleration means changing velocity, changing fields, propagating disturbance.
Magnetic monopoles don't exist (as far as we know). EM waves come from electric charges.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Accelerating charges create the changing fields that propagate as EM waves.
feedback.incorrect: Think about what creates changing fields.
feedback.explanation: Only accelerating charges create the changing electric fields that induce changing magnetic fields, creating self-propagating EM waves.

questions.text: All electromagnetic waves travel at different speeds in vacuum depending on their frequency.

modelAnswer.text: False. ALL electromagnetic waves travel at exactly the same speed c = 3.00 × 10⁸ m/s in vacuum, regardless of frequency or wavelength. Radio waves, visible light, gamma rays—all travel at c. This constancy is fundamental to special relativity. Different frequencies do travel at different speeds in materials (dispersion), but in vacuum, c is universal.

questions.text: An FM radio station broadcasts at 100.0 MHz. Calculate the wavelength of these radio waves.

steps.text: For all EM waves in vacuum: c = fλ

summary.text: When a wave meets its reflection, they interfere. At certain frequencies, this creates standing waves—points that don't move (nodes) and points of maximum motion (antinodes).

importance.text: Basis of lasers, optical cavities, and resonators. Shows how waves 'fit' into spaces. Every microwave oven and laser pointer uses standing wave principles.

explanations.text: Because forward and reflected waves have same frequency but opposite directions. They add constructively at some points (antinodes) and destructively at others (nodes).
Boundary conditions force nodes at certain points. The wave must 'fit' with nodes at boundaries. Only certain wavelengths satisfy this—quantization emerges from geometry.
It's an eigenvalue problem. The cavity imposes boundary conditions on Maxwell's equations. Solutions are discrete eigenmodes—the allowed standing wave patterns.
Waves + boundaries = discrete frequencies.

options.explanation: This assumes each loop is one wavelength. Actually, each loop is half a wavelength.
Correct! 3 loops = 3 × λ/2, so L = 3λ/2. Therefore λ = 2L/3 = 40 cm
This would be true for only one loop. With 3 loops, wavelength is shorter.
This multiplies instead of dividing. More loops mean shorter wavelength.

feedback.correct: Excellent! You recognized that each loop represents λ/2.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: for nodes at both ends, L = nλ/2 where n is the number of loops.
feedback.explanation: With nodes at both ends and 3 loops: L = 3λ/2, so 60 = 3λ/2, giving λ = 40 cm

summary.text: Waves bend around obstacles and spread through openings. Amount of spreading depends on λ/w ratio—wavelength compared to gap width. Bigger ratio = more spreading.

importance.text: Sets fundamental limit on imaging resolution. Why electron microscopes beat optical ones. Why radio waves go around buildings but light doesn't. Diffraction is everywhere.

explanations.text: Because waves explore all paths. Near edges, some paths are blocked, creating an imbalance. The wave 'leaks' into the shadow region. Smaller gaps relative to wavelength = more bending.
Huygens' principle: every point acts as a new source. At gaps, edge sources aren't balanced by neighbors, so waves spread. The λ/w ratio determines the angular spread.
It's the uncertainty principle for waves. Constraining position (small gap) increases momentum uncertainty (angular spread). Δx·Δp ≥ ℏ/2 manifests as diffraction.
Squeeze waves spatially → they spread angularly.

questions.text: Which combination produces the most diffraction?

options.text: Red light through a wide slit
options.explanation: Wide slit means small λ/w ratio, minimal diffraction.

options.text: Blue light through a wide slit
options.explanation: Blue has shorter wavelength than red, even smaller λ/w ratio.

options.text: Red light through a narrow slit
options.explanation: Correct! Large wavelength + small width = maximum λ/w ratio = most spreading

options.text: Blue light through a narrow slit
options.explanation: Narrow helps, but blue's shorter wavelength reduces the effect compared to red.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You maximized the λ/w ratio for maximum diffraction.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: diffraction increases with λ/w ratio.
feedback.explanation: Red light (long wavelength) through narrow slit (small width) gives the largest λ/w ratio and thus most diffraction.

questions.text: A microscope uses 500 nm green light. What's the smallest resolvable separation between two points if the objective aperture is 5.0 mm? Use θ ≈ λ/w for small angles.
Radio waves diffract around buildings more than visible light because radio waves have much longer wavelengths.

modelAnswer.text: True. Radio waves (wavelengths: meters) have much larger λ/w ratios than visible light (wavelengths: ~500 nm) when encountering building-sized obstacles. A 10 m building is only ~10 wavelengths for 1 m radio waves but ~20 million wavelengths for visible light. The huge λ/w ratio for radio waves means significant diffraction—they bend around buildings. Light's tiny λ/w ratio means negligible diffraction—sharp shadows.

summary.text: Two slits create two coherent sources. Their waves interfere—constructive (bright) where path difference = nλ, destructive (dark) where path difference = (n+½)λ. Result: interference fringes.

importance.text: Proved light is a wave (1801). Killed Newton's particle theory for a century. Now we know it shows wave nature, not wave exclusivity. Foundation of interferometry.

explanations.text: Because waves from two slits travel different distances to reach any point on the screen. When this path difference equals whole wavelengths, waves arrive in phase—bright. Half wavelengths—out of phase—dark.

Coherence is key. Same frequency, constant phase relationship. The single source ensuring coherence is clever—both slits sample the same wavefront. Path difference creates predictable phase differences.
It's quantum superposition made visible. Each photon goes through both slits (wave function spreads), interferes with itself. The pattern builds up photon by photon—wave statistics from particles.
One becomes two. Two interfere. Pattern emerges.

questions.text: For constructive interference (bright fringe) in Young's experiment, the path difference must be:

options.explanation: These give partial phase differences, not fully constructive.
These are odd multiples of λ/2, giving destructive interference (dark fringes).
Correct! Whole wavelengths mean waves arrive in phase, interfering constructively.
These give neither fully constructive nor destructive interference.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Path difference = nλ ensures waves arrive in phase.
feedback.incorrect: Think about when waves arrive in phase.
feedback.explanation: Path difference of nλ (n = 0,1,2,...) means waves complete whole cycles, arriving in phase for constructive interference.

questions.text: In Young's experiment, 600 nm light passes through slits 0.50 mm apart. The screen is 2.0 m away. Find the fringe spacing.
If you halve both the wavelength and the slit separation in Young's experiment, the fringe spacing:

options.explanation: Correct! Δx = λL/d. Halving both λ and d leaves Δx unchanged.
Check the formula. Both λ and d are halved.
This would happen if only λ were halved.
This would require d to decrease more than λ.

feedback.correct: Excellent! You see that λ and d have opposite effects on fringe spacing.
feedback.incorrect: Apply Δx = λL/d with both λ and d halved.
feedback.explanation: Δx = λL/d. If both λ → λ/2 and d → d/2, then Δx = (λ/2)L/(d/2) = λL/d. No change!

summary.text: Light energy comes in discrete packets—photons. Each photon carries energy E = hf. No half photons. Energy is granular, not continuous. Planck's constant h sets the grain size.

importance.text: Birth of quantum mechanics. Explained blackbody radiation, photoelectric effect, and atomic spectra. Shows nature is fundamentally discrete at small scales. h is nature's pixel size.

explanations.text: Because energy exchange between light and matter happens in discrete chunks. Planck discovered this solving the ultraviolet catastrophe. Classical physics predicted infinite energy—quantization saved it.
The electromagnetic field has quantum states like a harmonic oscillator. Energy levels are En = nhf. Photons are excitations between levels—always carrying energy differences of hf.
It's about action quantization. Action (energy × time) comes in units of ℏ. The uncertainty principle ΔE·Δt ≥ ℏ/2 means definite frequency requires energy quantization.
Nature's currency is discrete. No spare change.

questions.text: Calculate the energy of a photon of red light (λ = 700 nm) in both joules and electron-volts.
A UV photon has 3 times the frequency of a red photon. How do their energies compare?

options.explanation: Higher frequency means higher energy, not lower.
E = hf. Different frequencies mean different energies.
Correct! E = hf. Triple the frequency = triple the energy.
Energy is linear in frequency, not quadratic.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Energy is directly proportional to frequency.
feedback.incorrect: Remember E = hf. How does E change with f?
feedback.explanation: E = hf shows direct proportionality. 3× frequency means 3× energy.

questions.text: Photons have no mass, therefore they cannot have momentum.

modelAnswer.text: False. While photons are massless, they DO carry momentum given by p = E/c = hf/c = h/λ. This seems paradoxical from p = mv, but relativistically, momentum doesn't require mass. The full relation is E² = (pc)² + (mc²)². For photons, m = 0, so E = pc, giving p = E/c. Light pressure, solar sails, and optical tweezers all demonstrate photon momentum.

summary.text: Light ejects electrons from metals. But only above threshold frequency—intensity doesn't matter. Einstein: light comes as photons. One photon, one electron. Need hf > φ to escape.

importance.text: Killed classical wave theory of light. Won Einstein his Nobel (not relativity!). Proves particle nature. Birth of quantum mechanics. Every solar cell and photosensor uses it.

explanations.text: Because electrons need minimum energy φ (work function) to escape the metal. Light delivers energy in photon chunks hf. If hf < φ, no escape—no matter how many photons.

It's about energy concentration. Waves spread energy over area. But photoelectric emission is point-like—one electron absorbs one photon instantly. Only particles can deliver concentrated energy packets.
Quantum field theory: photon is destroyed, electron is excited. Energy-momentum conservation at a vertex. The metal provides momentum balance, electron takes energy hf minus binding energy φ.
One photon kicks one electron. Energy matters, not intensity.

questions.text: In the photoelectric effect, increasing light intensity (keeping frequency constant) will:

options.text: Increase maximum kinetic energy of electrons
options.explanation: KE_max depends only on frequency (hf - φ), not intensity.

options.text: Increase the number of electrons ejected
options.explanation: Correct! More photons = more electrons, but each has same maximum energy.
Work function is a material property, unchangeable by light.
No amount of sub-threshold photons can sum to eject an electron.

feedback.correct: Exactly! Intensity affects quantity, not quality of photoelectrons.
feedback.incorrect: Think about what intensity means in photon terms.
feedback.explanation: Higher intensity = more photons = more electrons ejected. But each photon still has energy hf, so maximum KE unchanged.

questions.text: Light of wavelength 400 nm ejects electrons from a metal with maximum kinetic energy 0.92 eV. Find the work function.
In a graph of maximum KE vs frequency for photoelectric effect, what does the x-intercept represent?

options.explanation: Planck's constant is the slope, not the intercept.
Work function is the y-intercept (when f = 0), not x-intercept.
Correct! At x-intercept, KE = 0, so hf = φ, giving f = φ/h (threshold).
This would be derived from threshold frequency, not directly the intercept.

feedback.correct: Excellent! You understand the graphical representation.
feedback.incorrect: At x-intercept, KE = 0. What does this mean?
feedback.explanation: X-intercept: KE = 0 = hf - φ, so f = φ/h. This is the threshold frequency below which no emission occurs.

summary.text: Fire electrons at crystals—get diffraction patterns. Just like X-rays. Particles creating wave patterns. Matter has wave nature. Everything is wavy at small scales.

importance.text: Proved de Broglie right—matter has wave properties. Enabled electron microscopes (better than light microscopes). Shows wave-particle duality is universal, not just for light.

explanations.text: Because electrons have wavelength λ = h/p. When λ is comparable to crystal spacing, diffraction occurs. Fast electrons = short λ = atomic-scale diffraction.
Quantum mechanics says particles are wave packets. The wave function Ψ spreads through the crystal, interfering with itself. |Ψ|² gives probability—creating the pattern.
It's path integral formulation. Electrons explore all paths through crystal. Paths differ by phases e^(iS/ℏ). Most cancel, some reinforce—diffraction emerges from quantum interference.
Particles are waves. Waves are particles. Both. Neither.

questions.text: Electron diffraction patterns differ from X-ray diffraction patterns because:

options.text: Electrons are particles, X-rays are waves
options.explanation: Both show wave behavior in diffraction. The distinction isn't fundamental.

options.text: Electrons interact more strongly with matter
options.explanation: Correct! Electrons are charged, interacting via Coulomb force. X-rays interact weakly.
Electrons definitely diffract—that's the whole point!
X-rays have wavelength comparable to atomic spacing, enabling diffraction.

feedback.correct: Perfect! The charged nature of electrons makes a key difference.
feedback.incorrect: Think about how electrons and photons interact with atoms.
feedback.explanation: Electrons interact strongly via electric forces with atomic electrons and nuclei. This makes electron diffraction surface-sensitive, while X-rays penetrate deeply.

questions.text: Electron diffraction patterns prove that electrons are actually waves, not particles.

modelAnswer.text: False. Electron diffraction proves electrons have wave PROPERTIES, not that they ARE waves. They also show particle properties (like leaving discrete spots on detectors). Electrons, like all quantum objects, exhibit wave-particle duality—they're neither purely waves nor purely particles but something that can manifest either behavior depending on measurement. The diffraction pattern emerges from wave-like propagation, but each electron hits the screen at a definite point like a particle.

summary.text: Every moving particle has wavelength λ = h/p. Smaller momentum = longer wavelength. Fast/heavy things have tiny wavelengths. Slow/light things get wavy. Universal wave-particle recipe.

importance.text: Unifies waves and particles. Explains why we don't see baseball diffraction (λ too small) but do see electron diffraction. Foundation of quantum mechanics and wave mechanics.

explanations.text: Because symmetry. If light (waves) has momentum p = h/λ, then matter (particles) should have wavelength λ = h/p. de Broglie guessed this—nature confirmed it.
It's about phase. A particle's quantum phase evolves as e^(ipx/ℏ). This gives wavelength λ = 2πℏ/p = h/p. The wave nature is in the phase.
Emerges from relativistic invariance. In 4D spacetime, energy-momentum is a 4-vector, and phase is a scalar. The relation E = hf, p = h/λ preserves Lorentz invariance.
Everything waves. How much? λ = h/p tells you.

steps.text: Electron gains kinetic energy: KE = eV = 100 eV = 1.60 × 10⁻¹⁷ J

options.explanation: Everything is quantum. But quantum effects can be negligible.

options.text: Their de Broglie wavelength is extremely small
options.explanation: Correct! λ = h/p. Large mass and speed give tiny wavelength, no observable diffraction.
All matter has wave properties via λ = h/p.
Actually, slower would give longer wavelength. But mass dominates.

feedback.correct: Exactly! Macroscopic objects have negligible wavelengths.
feedback.incorrect: Calculate λ = h/p for a typical baseball.
feedback.explanation: A 0.15 kg baseball at 40 m/s has λ = 6.63×10⁻³⁴/(0.15×40) = 1.1×10⁻³⁴ m. This is 10²⁴ times smaller than an atom!

questions.text: An electron and proton have the same kinetic energy. Which has longer de Broglie wavelength?

options.explanation: Correct! Same KE but electron has less mass, so less momentum, thus longer wavelength.
Heavier particle has more momentum at same KE, shorter wavelength.
Same KE doesn't mean same momentum. p = √(2mKE) depends on mass.
We can determine: lighter particle has longer wavelength at same KE.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You understand the KE-momentum-wavelength relationship.
feedback.incorrect: For same KE, how does momentum depend on mass?
feedback.explanation: KE = p²/2m, so p = √(2mKE). Heavier mass → larger momentum → shorter wavelength. Electron wins.

options.explanation: Individual dots appear random, but pattern emerges over time.

options.text: Each photon creates a complete interference pattern
options.explanation: Single photons make single dots. Pattern needs many photons.

options.text: Dots build up to form interference pattern
options.explanation: Correct! Each photon is a dot, but statistical pattern shows wave interference.

options.text: Photons only go through one slit
options.explanation: This would give no interference. Pattern proves both-slit passage.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You understand the statistical nature of quantum mechanics.
feedback.incorrect: Think about how individual detection events relate to the overall pattern.
feedback.explanation: Each photon hits as a particle (dot) but the accumulation reveals wave interference. Quantum mechanics is statistical.

questions.text: If we determine which slit a photon passes through in a double-slit experiment, the interference pattern remains unchanged.

modelAnswer.text: False. Determining which slit destroys the interference pattern! This is the heart of quantum mechanics: measurement changes the system. When you know the path (particle property), you lose interference (wave property). It's not about physical disturbance—even 'gentle' measurements that determine the path destroy interference. This complementarity is fundamental: you can have wave behavior OR particle trajectory information, never both.

questions.text: Wave-particle duality means:

options.text: Objects switch between being waves and particles
options.explanation: They don't switch—they're always both. Measurement reveals one aspect.

options.text: Half the object is wave, half is particle
options.explanation: Not divided—the whole object has both properties.

options.text: Objects exhibit both wave and particle properties
options.explanation: Correct! All quantum objects show both behaviors depending on measurement.

options.text: Scientists can't decide what light really is
options.explanation: We understand it well—it's quantum, beyond classical categories.

feedback.correct: Exactly! Duality is about complementary properties.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what 'duality' means in quantum context.
feedback.explanation: Wave-particle duality: quantum objects have both wave and particle properties. Which manifests depends on measurement type.

summary.text: Newton works until speeds approach c. Then everything breaks. Time isn't absolute. Space isn't fixed. Simultaneity isn't universal. Welcome to Einstein's universe.

importance.text: Shows our intuition is limited to low speeds. Reality is relativistic—GPS satellites need corrections. Particle accelerators need relativistic design. The universe is weirder than Newton imagined.

explanations.text: Because Newton assumes instantaneous action and absolute time. But information can't travel faster than c. This speed limit breaks absolute simultaneity and fixed time.
Space and time are linked. Motion through space affects passage through time. At low speeds, this is negligible. Near c, the mixing becomes extreme. Spacetime is the reality.
It's geometry. We live in 4D spacetime with Lorentzian metric. 'Motion' is rotation in spacetime. Classical mechanics assumes Euclidean 3D + separate time. Wrong geometry = wrong physics.
High speed reveals spacetime's true nature.

questions.text: Classical mechanics fails at high speeds because:

options.explanation: Friction isn't the issue. The problem is deeper—spacetime itself.

options.text: It assumes absolute time and space
options.explanation: Correct! Classical physics assumes universal time, but time is relative at high speeds.

options.text: Objects become too small to measure
options.explanation: Size isn't the issue. Time and space themselves change.
Special relativity ignores gravity. It's about speed, not gravitational effects.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You identified the core assumption that breaks down.
feedback.incorrect: Think about Newton's assumptions about space and time.
feedback.explanation: Classical mechanics assumes everyone agrees on time intervals and simultaneity. Relativity shows these are frame-dependent.

questions.text: In classical mechanics, there's no fundamental speed limit, so objects can theoretically reach any speed given enough force.

modelAnswer.text: True. In Newtonian mechanics, F = ma means constant force gives constant acceleration forever. There's no speed limit—velocities can add without bound. If you accelerate at 10 m/s² for a year, classical physics says you'd reach 3.15 × 10⁸ m/s, exceeding light speed. Reality doesn't work this way. As v approaches c, more force is needed for same acceleration. The universe has a speed limit: c.

summary.text: 1) Physics laws are same in all inertial frames. 2) Light speed c is constant for all observers. Simple statements, revolutionary consequences. These two ideas rebuild physics.

importance.text: Foundation of modern physics. From these, all of special relativity follows: time dilation, length contraction, E=mc². Shows how simple principles can revolutionize understanding.

explanations.text: First: no special reference frame exists. Motion is relative. Second: light doesn't follow velocity addition. These conflict with classical physics but match experiments.
Electromagnetism demands it. Maxwell's equations give c = 1/√(ε₀μ₀), no velocity dependence. Either Maxwell is wrong or mechanics needs fixing. Einstein fixed mechanics.
It's about symmetry. The Poincaré group (spacetime symmetries) includes boosts that mix space and time. The invariant speed emerges naturally from the group structure.
No preferred frame + constant c = relativity.

questions.text: You're on a train moving at 0.5c. You measure the speed of light from a stationary lamp. You get:

options.explanation: This would be c - v in classical physics. But light doesn't follow classical rules.
Correct! Second postulate: all observers measure same c, regardless of motion.
This would be c + v classically. But nothing exceeds c.
Direction doesn't matter. c is constant in all directions for all observers.

feedback.correct: Excellent! You understand the constancy of light speed.
feedback.incorrect: Remember Einstein's second postulate.
feedback.explanation: The second postulate states c is constant for ALL observers, regardless of their motion or the source's motion.

questions.text: Einstein's first postulate means that there is no experiment you can do to detect uniform motion.

modelAnswer.text: True. The principle of relativity states that all inertial frames are equivalent for physics laws. If you're in a smoothly moving train with no windows, no experiment inside can tell you whether you're moving or stationary. Drop a ball—it falls straight down. All physics works normally. Only acceleration or rotation can be detected internally. This is why you can pour coffee on a smooth flight—uniform motion is undetectable from within.

questions.text: Why do Einstein's postulates conflict with classical mechanics?

options.text: Classical mechanics has no speed limit
options.explanation: True but not the core conflict. The issue is deeper.

options.text: They require absolute simultaneity to be abandoned
options.explanation: Correct! Constant c for all observers means time and space must be relative.
Newton studied light extensively. The conflict is conceptual, not informational.

options.text: Classical mechanics only works on Earth
options.explanation: Classical mechanics works everywhere at low speeds. The issue is conceptual.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You see how constant c forces us to abandon absolute time.
feedback.incorrect: Think about what constant c means for simultaneity.
feedback.explanation: If light speed is constant for all observers, then time and space must adjust. This breaks absolute simultaneity—the core of classical mechanics.

summary.text: Tried to detect Earth's motion through 'ether' using light interference. Found nothing. No ether wind. Light speed same in all directions. Null result that changed physics.

importance.text: Most important null result in physics. Killed ether theory. Paved way for relativity. Shows negative results can be revolutionary. Sometimes finding nothing is finding everything.

explanations.text: Expected light to travel at c+v in Earth's direction, c-v opposite. This would create interference pattern shifts when apparatus rotated. No shifts found. Light speed constant.
If ether existed, Earth moving through it should create 'ether wind.' Like sound in air, light in ether should show relative motion. But light needs no medium—it's electromagnetic field oscillation.
The null result reveals spacetime structure. There's no absolute reference frame. The symmetry of physics under boosts (Lorentz invariance) means no ether can exist.
No ether. No absolute frame. Light speed constant.

questions.text: The Michelson-Morley experiment used interference to detect:

options.explanation: They weren't measuring c directly, but looking for variations in c.
Correct! They expected to find ether wind from Earth's orbital motion.
This came much later. M-M was about light and ether.
Wavelength was known. They sought motion effects.

feedback.correct: Exactly! They expected to detect our motion through the hypothetical ether.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what 'ether wind' would reveal.
feedback.explanation: Scientists thought light needed a medium (ether). Earth's motion through it should create detectable effects. Finding none was revolutionary.

questions.text: The Michelson-Morley null result proved that light travels through empty space at varying speeds.

modelAnswer.text: False. The null result showed light travels at the SAME speed in all directions, regardless of Earth's motion. They expected to find speed variations due to Earth moving through the ether—faster in one direction, slower in the opposite. Instead, they found no variation at all. This constant speed of light, independent of observer motion, became Einstein's second postulate and led directly to special relativity.

summary.text: Moving clocks run slow. Time between events is shortest in rest frame (proper time t₀). Moving observers see dilated time t = γt₀. The faster you go, the slower your clock.

importance.text: GPS satellites need corrections. Cosmic ray muons reach Earth. Particle accelerators see extended lifetimes. Not sci-fi—daily engineering reality. Time is relative.

explanations.text: Because speed of light is constant. If light clock ticks via light bouncing between mirrors, moving clock's light travels diagonal path—longer distance, same speed = more time.
Time and space mix under boosts. Motion through space reduces motion through time. Total 'speed' through spacetime always equals c. More spatial motion = less temporal motion.
Lorentz transformation preserves spacetime interval: -(ct)² + x² = -(ct')² + x'². This invariance requires time dilation. It's geometric—like shadows changing with rotation.
Fast motion = slow aging. Twin paradox is real.

questions.text: Muons created 10 km up have 2.2 μs half-life. At 0.99c, what fraction reach Earth? Without relativity?
GPS satellites need time corrections due to:

options.explanation: Velocity contributes, but there's another effect too.
Gravity contributes, but there's another effect too.
Correct! Velocity slows clocks (SR), weaker gravity speeds them up (GR).
Atmosphere affects signals, not satellite clocks themselves.

feedback.correct: Perfect! GPS needs both relativistic corrections.
feedback.incorrect: Consider all effects on orbiting clocks.
feedback.explanation: Special relativity: motion slows clocks by ~7 μs/day. General relativity: weaker gravity speeds clocks by ~45 μs/day. Net: +38 μs/day correction needed.

questions.text: Proper time is always the longest time interval measured between two events.

modelAnswer.text: False. Proper time (t₀) is always the SHORTEST time interval between events. It's measured by a clock present at both events (rest frame). All other observers see dilated time t = γt₀ where γ > 1. Your wristwatch measures proper time for your worldline. Everyone else sees your clock running slow. This is why the traveling twin ages less—they experience less proper time.

summary.text: Moving objects are shorter along motion direction. Rest length (proper length L₀) is longest. Moving observers measure contracted length L = L₀/γ. Space itself contracts.

importance.text: Explains muon survival from Earth's view. Particle accelerators must account for contracted targets. Not optical illusion—space really contracts. Complements time dilation.

explanations.text: Because simultaneity is relative. Length means 'distance between simultaneous endpoints.' Different frames disagree on simultaneity, thus on length. Front and back aren't measured at same time.
Space and time rotate into each other under boosts. What one observer calls pure space, another sees as space-time mix. Length contraction is the spatial part of Lorentz transformation.
It preserves causality. If time dilates without length contracting, causality breaks. The exact factor γ for both ensures consistent physics. It's required by Lorentz invariance.
Motion shrinks space along direction of travel.

options.explanation: The proton sees the accelerator moving, so it's contracted.
Length contracts, not expands. Check your γ application.
Correct! γ = 7.09, so L = L₀/7.09. The accelerator is highly contracted.
Only at v = c would length go to zero. 0.99c gives finite contraction.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You applied length contraction from the proton's frame.
feedback.incorrect: From proton's view, the accelerator moves at 0.99c.
feedback.explanation: The proton sees the accelerator rushing past at 0.99c. With γ = 7.09, the accelerator appears contracted to L₀/7.09.

steps.text: From muon's view, Earth approaches at 0.99c and atmosphere is contracted

questions.text: Proper length is the length measured by an observer moving with respect to the object.

modelAnswer.text: False. Proper length (L₀) is the length measured in the object's REST frame—by an observer NOT moving relative to the object. It's the length you'd measure with a ruler at rest relative to the object. All moving observers measure shorter (contracted) lengths. Like proper time being the time in the rest frame, proper length is the length in the rest frame. 'Proper' means 'in its own frame.'

summary.text: Mass is frozen energy. E = mc² at rest, E = γmc² in motion. Total energy = kinetic + rest energy. Mass and energy are same thing in different forms. c² is the exchange rate.

importance.text: Powers the Sun. Explains nuclear energy. Shows mass isn't conserved—energy is. Every chemical reaction, every sunrise, every heartbeat converts tiny amounts of mass to energy.

explanations.text: Because energy and momentum form a 4-vector in spacetime. Rest mass is invariant magnitude. E² = (pc)² + (mc²)² is Pythagorean theorem in spacetime. At rest, E = mc².
Mass is energy of existence. Even stationary objects have energy from quantum fluctuations, binding forces, confined motion. c² converts between energy and mass units.
Noether's theorem: time translation symmetry gives energy conservation. In spacetime, this becomes 4-momentum conservation. The timelike component is E/c, including rest energy mc².
Mass is energy at rest. Energy is liberated mass.

questions.text: The Sun radiates 3.85 × 10²⁶ W. How much mass does it lose per second?

steps.text: Power = Energy/time, so Energy per second = 3.85 × 10²⁶ J
The Sun loses 4.28 billion kg every second!

questions.text: When electron meets positron, they annihilate. What's the minimum total photon energy?

options.explanation: This is one electron's rest energy. You have electron AND positron.
Correct! Two particles × 0.511 MeV each = 1.022 MeV minimum.
Minimum is fixed by rest masses. KE would add to this.
Energy is finite—just the combined rest energies minimum.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Rest mass completely converts to photon energy.
feedback.incorrect: Remember both particles contribute rest energy.
feedback.explanation: Electron + positron each have 0.511 MeV rest energy. Annihilation converts all 1.022 MeV to photons (usually two 511 keV gammas).

questions.text: An electron is accelerated to 0.8c. Find its kinetic energy in MeV. (Rest energy = 0.511 MeV)
In nuclear reactions, mass is conserved while energy can be created or destroyed.

modelAnswer.text: False. It's exactly opposite! Energy is ALWAYS conserved (including rest energy), while mass is NOT conserved. In nuclear reactions, some rest mass converts to kinetic energy or radiation. The total energy before equals total energy after, but the total rest mass decreases. This mass defect becomes energy via E = mc². Example: in fusion, four hydrogen nuclei have more mass than one helium nucleus. The difference powers stars.

summary.text: Same wavelength = same momentum, whether light or matter. p = h/λ works for both. Photons: p = E/c = hf/c = h/λ. Matter: p = mv = h/λ. Universal formula.

importance.text: Deep unification. Light and matter obey same wave-momentum relation. Not coincidence—it's fundamental. Shows wave-particle duality is universal law, not separate phenomena.

explanations.text: Because momentum is fundamentally linked to wavelength through quantum phase. Any wave packet—light or matter—has momentum inversely proportional to its wavelength.
It's Noether's theorem. Translation symmetry in space leads to momentum conservation. The quantum operator for momentum is -iℏ∂/∂x, giving plane waves e^(ipx/ℏ) with λ = h/p.
In quantum field theory, all particles are excitations of fields. The dispersion relation ω(k) differs (E = pc for photons, E = p²/2m for matter), but the fundamental k = 2π/λ = p/ℏ is universal.
One rule for all: p = h/λ. Light, matter, doesn't matter.

questions.text: A photon and electron have the same momentum. The photon has wavelength 2.0 nm. What's the electron's kinetic energy?

steps.text: Same momentum means same wavelength: λ_electron = 2.0 nm

questions.text: A photon and electron have the same wavelength. Which has more energy?

options.explanation: Not always. Depends on wavelength. At very short λ, photon wins.
Not always. At long wavelengths, electron's rest energy dominates.
Same wavelength means same momentum, not same energy.
Correct! At short λ, E_photon = pc > E_electron. At long λ, electron's rest energy dominates.

feedback.correct: Excellent! You see the energy depends on more than just momentum.
feedback.incorrect: Compare E = pc for photons vs E = √((pc)² + (mc²)²) for electrons.
feedback.explanation: Same λ means same p. For photons: E = pc. For electrons: E includes rest mass. At high p, pc dominates. At low p, mc² dominates.

summary.text: Atoms absorb/emit only specific frequencies. Each element has unique spectral fingerprint. Why? Electrons in discrete energy levels. Transitions between levels absorb/emit photons of exact energy E = hf.

importance.text: Proves atomic energy quantization. Each element's unique spectrum enables spectroscopy—identifying elements in stars, forensics, everything. Quantum mechanics' first major triumph.

explanations.text: Because electrons occupy discrete orbitals with specific energies. Can only jump between these levels. Each jump needs/releases exact energy difference as a photon: hf = E_initial - E_final.
Electrons are standing waves around nucleus. Only certain wavelengths 'fit'—like vibrations on a string. These standing wave patterns have discrete energies. No in-between states allowed.
Schrödinger equation in Coulomb potential has discrete eigenvalues. Bound states are quantized. The atomic Hamiltonian's spectrum is discrete, not continuous—mathematical necessity.
Atoms are quantum. Photons carry the energy difference.

steps.text: Given: λ = 656 nm (red light, Hα line)

questions.text: What's the difference between emission and absorption spectra?

options.explanation: Same wavelengths! Same energy gaps, just opposite direction.

options.text: Emission shows bright lines, absorption shows dark lines
options.explanation: Correct! Emission: atoms glow at specific λ. Absorption: atoms remove specific λ from continuum.
Temperature affects intensity, but both hot and cold atoms can emit/absorb.
Same energy! Just opposite processes: photon created vs absorbed.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You understand the complementary nature of emission and absorption.
feedback.incorrect: Think about what happens to light passing through vs emitted by atoms.
feedback.explanation: Emission: electrons fall, creating photons (bright lines). Absorption: electrons jump up, removing photons (dark lines in continuum).

questions.text: Sodium street lamps appear yellow because sodium atoms emit all wavelengths but mostly yellow.

modelAnswer.text: False. Sodium lamps appear yellow because sodium atoms emit very specific wavelengths, primarily the bright yellow doublet at 589.0 and 589.6 nm (the D-lines). This isn't broad emission—it's discrete spectral lines from specific electronic transitions (3p→3s). The intense yellow completely dominates sodium's emission spectrum, making the lamps appear monochromatic yellow. Each element has its characteristic spectral lines; sodium's happen to be intense in the yellow.

summary.text: Light and matter both show wave and particle behavior. Which you see depends on measurement. Single photon/electron double-slit: arrives as particle (dot), interferes as wave (pattern builds).

importance.text: Core quantum weirdness. Forces us beyond classical thinking. Not sometimes wave, sometimes particle—always both, measurement reveals one aspect. Complementarity principle.

explanations.text: Because quantum objects aren't classical waves OR particles. They're quantum fields/states that can manifest either property. Measurement type determines which property appears.

Wave function describes probability amplitudes. Spreads like wave, collapses to particle on measurement. The quantum state |ψ⟩ evolves continuously (wave-like) but measurements give discrete outcomes (particle-like).
Complementarity is fundamental. Position and momentum, wave and particle—these are incompatible observables. Heisenberg uncertainty ΔxΔp ≥ ℏ/2 ensures you can't have both simultaneously.
Not wave. Not particle. Quantum.

questions.text: In single-photon double-slit experiment, what happens as photons accumulate?

options.explanation: Individual dots appear random, but pattern emerges over time.

options.text: Each photon creates a complete interference pattern
options.explanation: Single photons make single dots. Pattern needs many photons.

options.text: Dots build up to form interference pattern
options.explanation: Correct! Each photon is a dot, but statistical pattern shows wave interference.

options.text: Photons only go through one slit
options.explanation: This would give no interference. Pattern proves both-slit passage.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You understand the statistical nature of quantum mechanics.
feedback.incorrect: Think about how individual detection events relate to the overall pattern.
feedback.explanation: Each photon hits as a particle (dot) but the accumulation reveals wave interference. Quantum mechanics is statistical.

questions.text: If we determine which slit a photon passes through in a double-slit experiment, the interference pattern remains unchanged.

modelAnswer.text: False. Determining which slit destroys the interference pattern! This is the heart of quantum mechanics: measurement changes the system. When you know the path (particle property), you lose interference (wave property). It's not about physical disturbance—even 'gentle' measurements that determine the path destroy interference. This complementarity is fundamental: you can have wave behavior OR particle trajectory information, never both.

questions.text: Wave-particle duality means:

options.text: Objects switch between being waves and particles
options.explanation: They don't switch—they're always both. Measurement reveals one aspect.

options.text: Half the object is wave, half is particle
options.explanation: Not divided—the whole object has both properties.

options.text: Objects exhibit both wave and particle properties
options.explanation: Correct! All quantum objects show both behaviors depending on measurement.

options.text: Scientists can't decide what light really is
options.explanation: We understand it well—it's quantum, beyond classical categories.

feedback.correct: Exactly! Duality is about complementary properties.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what 'duality' means in quantum context.
feedback.explanation: Wave-particle duality: quantum objects have both wave and particle properties. Which manifests depends on measurement type.
